Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of 5-ALA Dosing for Fluorescence-Guided Resection of Malignant Glioma

Trial_Design.evidence: Conducted as a double-blind, randomised controlled trial, 21 patients with suspected malignant glioma were recruited at a single center.

Participants.evidence: Eligible participants were aged 18-75 years with a Karnofsky Performance Scale score of ≥70%.

Intervention.evidence: Patients were randomised to receive 0.2, 2, or 20 mg/kg of 5-ALA.

Objective.evidence: This study investigates the dose-efficacy relationship of five-aminolevulinic acid (5-ALA) in fluorescence-guided resection of malignant glioma.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the surgeon's intraoperative assessment of tumor fluorescence under violet-blue light.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Patients were randomised using block randomisation and allocation concealment via sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding included patients, surgeons, and outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 21 patients with suspected malignant glioma were recruited at a single center.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The 20 mg/kg group exhibited the strongest fluorescence in tumor core and margins, correlating with cell density.

Funding.evidence: Funding: Sponsored by Medac, Hamburg, Germany.
